newsitem.title: USA: FTC find Gerber babyfood claim "deceptive".
newsitem.headline: FTC find Gerber babyfood claim "deceptive".

text.p: Gerber has promised to halt "deceptive" claims that four out of five pediatricians recommend its baby food, the government announced Wednesday.
The Federal Trade Commission announced that Gerber Products Co. relied on a survey of 562 doctors that found only 67 -- barely more than one in 10 -- recommended Gerber baby food.

"Advertising that relies upon deceptive doctor recommendations for baby foods is especially troubling in as much as accurate expert advise is critical to reaching these important decisions about child care," Jodie Bernstein, director of the FTC Bureau of Consumer Protection, said in a statement.
Bernstein said the ad campaign, which ran on television, radio and in print, "skewed the results of the study by weeding out doctors" who didn't give the desired answers.
The study found that of the 562 doctors surveyed, 408 recommended baby food at least once a week, 76 recommended a specific brand of baby food and 67 recommend Gerber brand.

Gerber advertised that four out of five doctors who recommended baby food recommend Gerber but in fact only 16 percent -- or 67 out of 408 -- recommended Gerber, the FTC said. Beyond that, the FTC said the ads "made a broader implied claim that four out of five pedicatricians recommend Gerber."
Gerber, a division of Swiss pharmaceutical and chemical company Novartis, acknowledged problems with its ad.

"We acknowledge the advertisement perhaps inaccurately confused the message of the survey," said Van Hindes, director of corporate affairs for Gerber, speaking from company headquarters in Fremont, Mich.
